abstract: E-mail messages sent among Federal Reserve staff members show the pressure regulators put on Bank of America to complete its deal for Merrill Lynch.
snippet: E-mail messages sent among Federal Reserve staff members show the pressure regulators put on Bank of America to complete its deal for Merrill Lynch.
lead_paragraph: Alarm was rising inside the Federal Reserve. It was late December, and Fed officials were warning that Merrill Lynch — a brokerage firm that for many Americans was synonymous with Wall Street — was foundering even faster than many had feared.

headline.main: U.S. Saw Problems on the Way at Merrill

abstract: Kenneth Lewis of Bank of America told a Congressional panel that he had considered pulling out of the deal but that regulators had pressured him to complete it.
snippet: Kenneth Lewis of Bank of America told a Congressional panel that he had considered pulling out of the deal but that regulators had pressured him to complete it.
lead_paragraph: Flanked by a coterie of lawyers and lobbyists, Kenneth D. Lewis, Bank of America’s embattled chief executive, walked into yet another Congressional hearing room on Thursday as the sole witness in a merger drama that has shadowed his banking empire for months.

headline.main: Bank Chief Tells of U.S. Pressure to Buy Merrill Lynch
headline.print_headline: Bank Chief Says U.S. Pushed Merrill Deal

byline.original: By Louise Story and Jo Becker

abstract: Kenneth D. Lewis, the chief executive of Bank of America, testified before a Congressional committee on Thursday that he was pressured by the government late last year to buy Merrill Lynch.
snippet: Kenneth D. Lewis, the chief executive of Bank of America, testified before a Congressional committee on Thursday that he was pressured by the government late last year to buy Merrill Lynch.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth D. Lewis, the chief executive of Bank of America, testified before a Congressional committee on Thursday that he was pressured by the government late last year to buy Merrill Lynch, Louise Story of The New York Times reported.

headline.main: Lewis Says U.S. Pressured BofA to Buy Merrill

abstract: House lawmakers on Thursday debated whether executive pay should be curbed at all companies — and not just at financial institutions receiving a federal lifeline.
snippet: House lawmakers on Thursday debated whether executive pay should be curbed at all companies — and not just at financial institutions receiving a federal lifeline.
lead_paragraph: Less than a day after the Obama administration announced a plan to set executive pay levels at bailed-out companies like Citigroup and Bank of America, a dispute broke out among members of a House panel over the issue of regulating corporate compensation.

headline.main: Should Pay Curbs Go Beyond the TARP?
